manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: API allowing a project to have multiple configurations
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Provides an API which module developers can use to support mulitple configurations for a project type.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.netbeans.modules.projectapi/1 > 1.9.1, org.netbeans.modules.projectuiapi/1 > 1.13.1.5, org.openide.nodes > 6.7.1, org.openide.util > 6.8.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: A terminal emulator library written in Java.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: A pure-Java terminal emulator capable of handling usual cursor control sequences, scrolling, selection, copying, redirection of output, and so on. Used in NetBeans for the Output Window.

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Supports the C/C++ Code Model - contains ANTLR parser generator library
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Custom ANTLR parser generator version that is used by the implementation of C/C++ Code Model API

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: API that represents C/C++ code
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Contains API that represents C/C++ code
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.openide.util > 6.8.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: APT presentation for files with preprocessor
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: APT presentation for files with preprocessor directives
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.netbeans.modules.cnd.antlr > 2.7.5

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: C/C++ Class View

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Supports debugging of native programs with gdb
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Basic debugger support using GNU's gdb debugger. While part of the C/C++ Development Pack, this debugger will debug any high level language compiled by the appropriate compilers and supported by gdb.

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Short-Description: Supports C/C++ projects
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Supports C/C++ projects using make. The project typically is a native development project written in C or C++. However, since make is not limited to these languages, in reality a Make Project can be used to build just about anything.
